answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**

1. **Frame 1** clearly shows a roadside sign with a left‐turn arrow labeled “ONLY,” and on the pavement immediately in front of the camera there is a large painted arrow turning left.  
2. **Frame 2** reconfirms the same left‐arrow “ONLY” pavement marking in the camera’s lane. You can also see the “ONLY” sign (arrow pointing left) mounted near the signal head overhead.  
3. **Frames 3–5** continue to show the same dedicated‐left‐turn signage and markings (that “ONLY” arrow on both the roadway and on the signs). There are no markings or signs suggesting that this lane also allows going straight or right.

**Contextual Reasoning**

All the signage and lane‐use arrows visible in these frames indicate the dashcam/ego vehicle is positioned in a dedicated left‐turn lane—that is, the “left turn only” lane. No pavement arrow or overhead sign suggests a combined left‐or‐straight movement is allowed from this lane. Adjacent lanes likely have different maneuvers, but from the ego’s lane there is no indication of any option besides left turn.

**Matching to Answer Choices**

• (A) Turn left only ⇒ Matches the “ONLY” signs and the pavement arrow in the ego lane.  
• (B) Turn left and go straight ⇒ Conflicts with the clear “ONLY” left‐turn signs.  
• (C) Go straight only ⇒ Conflicts with the left‐turn‐only markings.  
• (D) Turn right and go straight ⇒ Conflicts with the left‐turn‐only markings.

**Provide the Best Answer**

<answer>A</answer>
